awd_titl_txt: US Ignite: Focus Area 1: An Integrated Reconfigurable Control and Self-Organizing Communication Framework for Advanced Community Resilience Microgrids
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States is experiencing an increasing frequency of catastrophic weather events that inflict serious social and economic impacts. A critical issue associated with such catastrophes is the availability of electricity for the recovery efforts. Community resilience microgrids can connect critical loads in the community and share the distributed energy resources of multiple providers to enhance the availability of electricity supply during disruptions. However, community resilience microgrids are complex networked systems, and their operation can be often interrupted or halted due to the cascaded growth of failures in interconnected electrical and communications components or the unwillingness or inability of individual microgrid partners to respond. In order to enable the full functionality of community resilience microgrids, this project investigates an integrated reconfigurable control and self-organizing communication framework for enhancing operations in both grid-connected and islanded modes. The effectiveness and benefit of the proposed framework will be demonstrated and evaluated through the hardware-in-the-loop simulation and an actual community microgrid project, which will ultimately provide a model for the successful deployment of community resilience microgrids in the U.S. and beyond. In addition to including doctoral students in research and creating educational materials for the next generation operators and researchers of electrical and communications systems, projects will involve underrepresented students in evaluating social, economic, and resilience benefits of integrated control and communication approaches.

Coordinated dynamic control strategies for distributed energy resources and loads of multiple owners across different timescales, together with their distinct communication requirements, are the key to the resilient and economic operation of community microgrids in both grid-connected and islanded modes. This research will address these challenges by (1) exploring a hierarchically reconfigurable centralized/distributed control strategy to optimally manage power flows of distribution lines, dispatches of distributed energy resources and flexible loads, and the voltage and frequency of the microgrid across multiple timescales; (2) investigating a self-organizing infrastructure with network topology adjustment and multi-scale data aggregation for flexible, fast, and reliable communication; (3) developing an integrated reconfigurable control and self-organizing communication framework to study the interdependency and interaction between control strategies and communication requirements; and (4) validating, demonstrating, and promoting the developed framework through the hardware-in-the-loop simulation and an ongoing community microgrid project.

por.por_cntn:
The United States is experiencing an increasing number of catastrophic weather events that inflict major social and financial impacts at national, regional, and local levels, while a critical issue associated with such events is the availability of electrical energy to provide service for the recovery effort. Community resilience microgrids, as an emerging technology, can connect critical loads in the community and share distributed energy resources of multiple owners, especially renewable sources, to enhance resilient electricity supply, ultimately reducing the overall impact of and improving recovery to critical events for the entire community.

However, community resilience microgrids cannot become widely applied until several key challenges for their operations and controls are adequately resolved. Specifically, a community resilience microgrid is not only a network interconnecting distributed energy resources and loads of multiple owners through distribution lines, but also overlaid with a communication and control system that gathers inputs and sends out control signals to multiple owners for enabling resilient and economic operations. Indeed, community resilience microgrids are complex networked systems whose operation and control could be often interrupted or halted due to the cascaded growth of failures in interconnected power and communication components, or the unwillingness and inability of individual owners.

In order to enable the full functionality and achieve the suite of electrical, economic, and societal benefits of community resilience microgrids, this project has thoroughly investigated an integrated reconfigurable control and self-organizing communication framework for enhancing their resilient and economic operations in both grid-connected and islanded modes. Specifically, the integrated reconfigurable control and self-organizing communication framework has explored coordinated dynamic control strategies for distributed energy resources and loads of multiple owners across different timescales, together with their distinct communication requirements, to the resilient and economic operation of community microgrids. The detailed research activities include: (i) exploring a hierarchically reconfigurable centralized/distributed control strategy to optimally manage power flows of distribution lines, dispatches of distributed energy resources and flexible loads, as well as voltage and frequency of the microgrid across multiple timescales; (ii) investigating a self-organizing infrastructure with network topology adjustment and multi-scale data aggregation for the flexible, fast, and reliable communication; (iii) developing an integrated reconfigurable control and self-organizing communication framework to study the interdependency and interaction between control strategies and communication requirements; and (iv) validating, demonstrating, and promoting the developed framework through the hardware-in-the-loop simulation and an on-going community microgrid project. Research results have been disseminated via the established industry and local community connections, ultimately generating direct and profound impacts to the community and society by helping them better understand how to manage available energy resources for achieving higher resilience standards.

In this project, a group of graduate and undergraduate students have been involved in various research and education activities. The team has published multiple journal and conference papers as well as technical presentations and invited talks to disseminate research results supported by this project. Some research findings have also been included in various courses at Stevens Institute of Technology and University of Ottawa. The related activities have experienced students with energy and social behavior research-related training to meet the next-generation smart grid workforce needs. Research and education results out of this project could also help increase public awareness and understanding of the complicated dynamic interactions between human behavior and smart technologies, promote the sound deployment of advanced energy techniques related to renewable energy and energy efficiency among various stakeholders, and appeal to researchers interested in research, education, and workforce development in this area.
